headline: Republican voters in Virginia will blame their party for health insurance increases
summary: A May 2025 KFF tracking poll found that 75% of uninsured Virginia adults skipped needed care due to cost, while 37% of insured adults faced similar barriers, illustrating bipartisan healthcare affordability concerns as Congress debates expiring premium tax credits that could leave 100,000 residents uninsured and create political risk for Republican representatives refusing to support extensions.

headline: Physician urges testing, vaccination as WV whooping cough cases continue at record high
summary: West Virginia's whooping cough cases reached 199 this year—the highest since 2010—driving state health officials and WVU physicians to recommend Tdap boosters for adults, especially those near infants; the surge exposes lower pre-school vaccination rates despite robust kindergarten immunization mandates and aligns with a national sixfold increase in cases.

headline: Del. Brandon Steele resigns from WV House, effective immediately
summary: West Virginia Del. Brandon Steele's resignation follows a December 2024 incident where he reportedly screamed at neighbors while intoxicated and handling assault rifles. After police reports and 911 calls were sent to House leadership and media in January 2025, Steele was removed as House Judiciary chairman. His wife's subsequent protective order and his eventual resignation demonstrate how public disturbances by elected officials trigger institutional political and policy consequences.

headline: Federal education cutbacks cause problems for Missouri school funding formula
summary: Missouri's K-12 funding formula overhaul is stalled after federal agencies discontinued essential regional wage data sources deemed "nonessential," forcing the state to freeze the dollar-value modifier until new legislation establishes alternative calculation methods, with the School Funding Modernization Task Force now delayed until its January 26 meeting to review working group recommendations.

headline: Fruitland residents speak out against plans to drill for oil and gas near neighborhoods
summary: Several Fruitland residents and city officials held a public protest at City Hall on Dec. 17, 2025, opposing Snake River Oil and Gas's integration order application to drill near residential neighborhoods, citing health, safety, and environmental risks. City Administrator Stuart Grimes spoke on behalf of the mayor and City Council against the proposal, which would facilitate drilling within hundreds of feet of homes. The gathering demonstrates local resistance to state law allowing energy companies to compel drilling on non-consenting properties after securing 55% of leases. The Idaho Oil and Gas Conservation Commission will accept written comments until Dec. 24 before a final decision due Jan. 30. The protest highlights the conflict between state energy development authority and community safety concerns.

headline: Maine considering more ways to push back on Trump’s deportation agenda
summary:
Approximately 120 people attended a July 21 Cumberland County Board of Commissioners meeting in Portland to urge termination of the county jail's contract with federal immigration authorities.
 This public gathering reflects sustained civic pressure that has influenced local policy, including the Wells Police Department ending its federal immigration partnership.
 The engagement occurs as Maine lawmakers prepare for the January legislative session to consider new proposals limiting local-federal immigration collaboration.
 These proposals include clarifying that jails may refuse federal detainees and protecting sensitive locations like schools and hospitals from enforcement.
 The public advocacy directly impacts the policy debate over Maine's role in federal immigration enforcement.

headline: Beshear request to help cover budget shortfall meets pushback from GOP state officials
summary: Kentucky faces a $156 million revenue shortfall, prompting Governor Beshear to propose 3% cuts to executive agencies and constitutional officers via unfilled vacancies, while exempting education, pensions, and public safety. Republican constitutional officers are refusing to comply, citing a new law granting them discretion to opt out of gubernatorial reduction requests. House Republican leadership opposes across-the-board cuts, arguing they risk harming essential services without distinguishing program effectiveness. The executive branch cuts would generate $77.7 million in General Fund savings, leaving the remainder of the shortfall's coverage unclear. The state maintains billions in its Budget Reserve Trust Fund as an alternative to uniform cuts.

headline: KY Supreme Court changes course, strikes down law singling out Jefferson County schools
summary: The Kentucky Supreme Court overturned a 2022 law 4-3 that would have shifted authority from Jefferson County Public Schools' elected board to its appointed superintendent, ruling it unconstitutional special legislation. The reversal followed a rehearing after a new justice joined the court, sparking political controversy including recusal demands and impeachment petitions. The majority opinion defended the decision as protecting against unreasonable targeting of a single district and preserving constitutional limits on legislative power over local school governance. The ruling limits the General Assembly's ability to enact narrow education laws and upholds elected school board authority. It directly impacts Kentucky's largest school district and sets precedent for statewide public education administration.

headline: As vaccination rates fall, Wisconsin reports two deaths of children from flu, COVID-19
summary: Wisconsin DHS reported two pediatric deaths from flu and COVID-19 with state vaccination rates at just 28% for flu and 10.6% for COVID-19, significantly below prior years. In response, officials are promoting the Vaccines for Children and Vaccines for Adults programs offering free or low-cost immunizations to uninsured residents. DHS attributes rising vaccine hesitancy to confusion over evolving CDC recommendations and stresses vaccination as the best prevention against severe complications like cardiac issues and encephalitis. The department monitors outbreaks through emergency room data, lab tests, and wastewater analysis, while recommending shots for all individuals six months and older. Public health officials urge residents to consult state and local health departments, community clinics, pharmacies, and primary care doctors for reliable vaccine information.

headline: Pipeline developer goes to ND Supreme Court seeking to block Greenpeace Netherlands lawsuit
summary: The North Dakota Supreme Court is reviewing whether to halt a Dutch lawsuit filed by Greenpeace International against Energy Transfer, stemming from the 2016-2017 Dakota Access Pipeline protests that drew thousands of activists to south-central North Dakota. Greenpeace backed the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe-led movement to halt pipeline construction and is defending against Energy Transfer's North Dakota lawsuit while pursuing EU free speech protections in Dutch courts. Energy Transfer argues the foreign action undermines North Dakota court authority and seeks to block it, while Greenpeace contends the cases are separate and North Dakota lacks jurisdiction over its Dutch entity. The dispute follows a reduced $660 million North Dakota jury verdict against Greenpeace related to protest activities. The Supreme Court's decision will establish precedent on whether state courts can restrain international litigation arising from domestic protest movements.

headline: Capital Prep sues over CT charter school funding process
summary: Capital Preparatory Charter School filed a lawsuit against the Connecticut Board of Education to reverse its October ruling that the Board lacks authority to determine charter school funding, which is currently controlled by the legislature under a 2015 law change. The legal action seeks to resolve the systemic conflict where schools can be approved—like Capital Prep's Middletown expansion was in March 2023 with the highest score—but remain unfunded due to legislative decisions. The case implicates Gov. Ned Lamont and key legislators (Senate President Looney, Sens. Lesser and Hochadel) who allegedly blocked Middletown's funding, highlighting a policy gap that affects school choice and transparency in Connecticut's K-12 education system.

headline: Billionaire Ray Dalio pledges $75 million to Connecticut kids
summary: The Dalios have granted tens of millions to Connecticut public schools over the years, though a $100 million initiative launched in 2019 that would have involved matching public funds fell apart after state lawmakers raised questions over transparency.

headline: Should CT fund its own SNAP program? Lamont, budget chair disagree
summary: Connecticut's state budget surpluses have averaged over $1.8 billion (8-9% of the General Fund) since 2017, which Sen. Cathy Osten cites as making a state-funded nutrition benefit feasible for 36,000 residents losing federal SNAP assistance; however, Gov. Lamont prefers directing $24.6 million to food banks instead of creating an ongoing state program, highlighting a political divide over using state funds to replace federal benefits.

headline: Reductions to Oklahoma child care subsidies to remain
summary: The Oklahoma Department of Human Services paused a $5 per child daily subsidy for school-age children due to exhausted federal relief funds, characterizing it as a budget-driven "pause" requiring $70 million in additional state funding from the Legislature to resume and stabilize the program; child care providers warn the funding delay is causing immediate facility closures and forcing them to personally subsidize operations, particularly harming rural areas.

headline: State reports bird flu outbreak in geese at two southwest Iowa lakes
summary: The Iowa DNR confirmed highly pathogenic avian influenza in Canada geese at two southern Iowa lakes, with the CDC noting the public health risk remains low despite over 70 human cases nationwide from exposure to infected poultry or dairy cattle; state officials advise residents to avoid contact with sick or dead birds, keep pets away, and report clusters of 20+ bird carcasses to local wildlife staff to help track disease impacts.

headline: Greenwood Leflore Hospital reaches deal with state Medicaid officials to repay remainder of its $5.5 million debt
summary: The Mississippi Division of Medicaid's demand for Greenwood Leflore Hospital to repay $5.5 million in overpayments threatens closure of the 35-bed facility that serves 300,000 patients in the medically underserved Delta region, with state and federal policy interventions—including legislative appeals and the Rural Community Hospital Demonstration Program—attempting to stabilize the hospital's finances amid already reduced services and upcoming federal Medicaid cuts.

headline: Envíanos información sobre avisos de ICE
summary: Hundreds of federal border agents deployed to Mississippi and New Orleans for "Operation Catahoula Crunch," a two-month enforcement action targeting 5,000 individuals with criminal records, though national data indicates over 70% of immigrant detainees lack criminal histories, with advocates reporting ICE presence across Mississippi including the Jackson metro area.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Trump health agency proposes rules to limit gender-affirming care for youth
summary: The Trump administration proposed CMS rules barring hospitals from providing gender transition treatment for minors as a condition of Medicare/Medicaid participation, effectively creating a nationwide ban, while the House passed legislation imposing federal criminal penalties of up to 10 years for medical professionals providing such care and prohibiting Medicaid funding for these procedures; the FDA also issued warning letters to 12 breast binder manufacturers for allegedly illegally marketing to children, and HHS seeks to reverse Biden-era disability protections for gender dysphoria, forcing doctors to choose between ethical obligations and federal funding loss.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: John F. Kennedy Center to be renamed the Trump-Kennedy Center, White House says
summary: Major artists and performers have boycotted the Kennedy Center following President Trump's political takeover, with Issa Rae and "Hamilton" canceling scheduled performances and dozens of "Les Misérables" cast members refusing to perform for Trump officials, demonstrating artistic protest against the administration's control of the cultural institution.

headline: New federal rules may threaten Vermont hospital funding over gender-affirming care for minors
summary: The Trump administration, via HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., proposed rules to cut off Medicaid and Medicare funding for hospitals that provide gender-affirming care to minors, directly threatening Vermont hospitals that rely on these programs for over two-thirds of inpatient payments; the move conflicts with Vermont's 2023 shield laws protecting such care as essential insurance coverage, though State Health Commissioner Rick Hildebrant and the University of Vermont Medical Center affirmed their commitment to continue providing evidence-based care despite potential federal changes, while advocates condemned the proposal as extortion threatening healthcare access for trans youth.

headline: South Dakota state economist says sluggish farm economy has held back sales tax revenues
summary: Gov. Larry Rhoden's budget address reported that overall sales tax revenue declined 0.6% in FY2025—the third decline in 30 years—due to a sluggish farm economy that cut farm equipment sales tax collections by over 20%. State Economist Derek Johnson noted FY2026 farm equipment collections remain down 16% year-to-date, but the most recent month showed the first year-over-year improvement in nearly two years. Overall sales tax revenues for FY2026 are up 4% so far, though the agricultural sector's weakness continues to have an outsized impact on the state's budget.

headline: SC House GOP seeks to mandate ICE partnership agreements at jails statewide
summary: A House GOP bill would mandate all South Carolina law enforcement agencies operating jails to sign 287(g) agreements with ICE, requiring annual proof of compliance to SLED and the attorney general's office under threat of state oversight or suspension. The legislation, sponsored by Rep. Travis Moore and 47 other Republicans, follows a surge in ICE partnerships under the Trump administration. It includes mandatory immigration training and would apply to 29 additional counties and four city police departments. The bill provides no state funding despite existing federal reimbursement and bonus programs for participating agencies. Currently, 20 sheriff's departments and several state agencies already participate in the program.

headline: NH Health and Human Services axes $4.3M in contracts in response to steep budget cuts
summary: The New Hampshire Legislature's two-year budget imposed a $51 million cut to the Department of Health and Human Services, which this week initiated $4.3 million in contract reductions affecting mental health services, home visits for at-risk families, child protective support, homeless shelters, and substance use programs. Commissioner Lori Weaver claimed the cuts align services with actual utilization and won't harm families, while Democratic Executive Councilor Karen Liot Hill warned of inevitable harm, and advocacy groups condemned the cuts as prioritizing tax cuts over social services, reflecting a partisan divide over fiscal policy impacts.

headline: ‘Punch in the gut’: Nurses at Beacon Kalamazoo hospital struggle under new, limited health benefits
summary: Beacon Health System's acquisition of Ascension Borgess hospitals has created public health access concerns as retired nurses lost Medigap reimbursements costing ~$2,700 annually and active staff lost short-term disability coverage; limited in-network providers in Kalamazoo also force healthcare workers to pay hundreds out-of-pocket for essential medical and mental health services, potentially reducing their healthcare utilization and undermining the health system's capacity to serve the community.

headline: Prairie Band Potawatomi leader says tribe has separated from ICE project
summary: The Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation terminated its $30 million federal contract with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to design migrant detention centers, with Tribal Council Chairman Joseph Rupnick announcing the complete separation on Wednesday. The contract, which tasked the tribe's affiliate KPB Services with due diligence and concept design for processing centers nationwide, drew scrutiny after Rupnick compared immigrant detention to the forced removal of Native Americans. Several tribal leaders involved in KPB Services were fired for their participation. Though the contract remained active in federal databases Thursday morning, Rupnick declared Prairie Band LLC is no longer affiliated with any ICE operations. The Tribal Council will convene in January to prevent future conflicts between the Nation's economic interests and its values.

headline: MBTA Communities fight heads back to the SJC
summary: Multiple Massachusetts towns are legally challenging the controversial MBTA Communities housing law as an unfunded mandate, creating political tension with state officials over compliance deadlines and penalties that could potentially spark public demonstrations or civil unrest.
